title: [BUG] helm install of 1.6.1 fails
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

Hi Team,

Steps provided in https://artifacthub.io/packages/helm/hertzbeat/hertzbeat doesn't work as the manager installation fails, because of postgres failure. Postgres fails when we provide the storage class as it mounts the pvc directly on to the folder on which postgres creates its files and errors out stating there is already a folder called lost+found. Providing value to "database.persistence.subPath" doesn't have any effect. 

To fix the DB issue, have to download the chart and then modify the file templates/database/statefulset.yaml and add the value for spec.containers.name.volumemounts.name.subpath and then package it and apply it from command line. But this doesn't make the manager come up on 1.6.1 but when i did the same change with 1.6.0 i was able to bring the entire solution up.

### Expected Behavior

https://artifacthub.io/packages/helm/hertzbeat/hertzbeat - following that document should bring the solution up

### Steps To Reproduce

https://artifacthub.io/packages/helm/hertzbeat/hertzbeat - follow the helm based install documented there

### Environment

```markdown
HertzBeat version(s):1.6.1 & 1.6.0
```

### Debug logs

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

you can fix the issue by adding {{ .Values.database.persistence.subPath }} to line number 66 of the file templates/databases/statefulset.yaml where it needs a subpath.

Thank & Regards

title: NA
body:
@tomsun28 : are you using a pvc/storageclass? if so iam 100% sure it wont as its not an issue with hetzbeat, rather an issue with how postgres 16(which is what hertz helm chart uses) checks for the files on the existing folder. Meaning it will find "lost+found" and error out stating its a mount path. Here is the error from the database container if you install it with storageclass

The files belonging to this database system will be owned by user "postgres".
This user must also own the server process.
The database cluster will be initialized with locale "en_US.utf8".
The default database encoding has accordingly been set to "UTF8".
The default text search configuration will be set to "english".
Data page checksums are disabled.
initdb: error: directory "/var/lib/postgresql/data" exists but is not empty
initdb: detail: It contains a lost+found directory, perhaps due to it being a mount point.
initdb: hint: Using a mount point directly as the data directory is not recommended.
Create a subdirectory under the mount point.

title: [Question] Keyword in HTTP monitor not working
body:
### Question

Hi Team,

There is a an option in HTTP monitor called "Keyword"(under Advanced) Which has the statement like "Enter the keyword which occurrences has to be monitored"  My expectation was that when we provide a word which is not in the website its monitoring it should trigger a warning/alert, but it does not. And tried to find the use of that value on the doc site and cannot seem to find anything related to that.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/16925a57-e66d-495a-95c6-0d41abb65886)

Is my expectation wrong? 

Thanks in advance

title: NA
body: hi, if you use 'Keyword' at http monitor ,it will only calulate as the metric : the num of 'keyword' at the response content;if you want 'keyword' trigger a warning/alert, you need enter Alerting#Thresholdï¼Œand set the regulation about keyword;

title: NA
body: @MasamiYui : Thank you, this works.

title: [Question] HTTP custom Monitor for a key word for second metric
body:
### Question

Hi Team,

I have followed the custom HTTP monitor using the following document https://hertzbeat.apache.org/docs/advanced/extend-http-example-token and have created first metric to capture the token and then created a second metric(named - awsstatus) to do a POST and iam getting the response as well which iam storing on a variable, but i dont see an option to make the monitor fail if the content is missing from the second metrics. Any help would be much appreciated.
`
metrics:
  # metrics - auth
  - name: auth
    # metrics scheduling priority(0->127)->(high->low), metrics with the same priority will be scheduled in parallel
    # priority 0's metrics is availability metrics, it will be scheduled first, only availability metrics collect success will the scheduling continue
    priority: 0
    # collect metrics content
    fields:
      # field-metric name, type-metric type(0-number,1-string), unit-metric unit('%','ms','MB'), label-whether it is a metrics label field
      - field: token
        type: 1
    # the protocol used for monitoring, eg: sql, ssh, http, telnet, wmi, snmp, sdk
    protocol: http
    # the config content when protocol is http
    http:
      # http host: ipv4 ipv6 domain
      host: ^_^host^_^
      # http port
      port: ^_^port^_^
      # http url
      url: ^_^uri^_^
      # http method: GET POST PUT DELETE PATCH
      method: POST
      # if enabled https
      ssl: ^_^ssl^_^
      payload: ^_^payload^_^
      # http request header content
      headers:
        content-type: ^_^contentType^_^
        ^_^headers^_^: ^_^headers^_^
      # http request params
      params:
        ^_^params^_^: ^_^params^_^
      # http response data parse type: default-hertzbeat rule, jsonpath-jsonpath script, website-for website monitoring, prometheus-prometheus exporter rule
      parseType: jsonPath
      parseScript: '$.token'
  - name: awsstatus
    # metrics scheduling priority(0->127)->(high->low), metrics with the same priority will be scheduled in parallel
    # priority 0's metrics is availability metrics, it will be scheduled first, only availability metrics collect success will the scheduling continue
    priority: 1
    # collect metrics content
    fields:
      # field-metric name, type-metric type(0-number,1-string), unit-metric unit('%','ms','MB'), label-whether it is a metrics label field
      - field: awsstatus
        type: 1
    # the protocol used for monitoring, eg: sql, ssh, http, telnet, wmi, snmp, sdk
    protocol: http
    # the config content when protocol is http
    http:
      # http host: ipv4 ipv6 domain
      host: ^_^host^_^
      # http port
      port: ^_^port^_^
      # http url
      url: /v1/chat
      # http method: GET POST PUT DELETE PATCH
      method: POST
      # if enabled https
      ssl: ^_^ssl^_^
      payload: '{xxxxxxxxxxxx}'
      # http request header content
      headers:
        content-type: application/json
        Authorization: Bearer ^o^token^o^
      # http response data parse type: default-hertzbeat rule, jsonpath-jsonpath script, website-for website monitoring, prometheus-prometheus exporter rule
      parseType: jsonPath
      parseScript: '$.type'
`

title: NA
body: Found the solution, and going to leave it for others if and when they need. Once the second metric is configured, a custom Threshold rule has to be created and have to choose the second metric as the monitoring object

title: [BUG] Monitor Status Update Not Synchronized in Query
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

Same issue as #2772 #2274

Specific Behavior:
After shutting down the monitored service and waiting for the next data collection, the status field of the corresponding record in the hzb_monitor table changes to 2 (unreachable). However, refreshing the frontend page still shows the service as online, and the API response also returns outdated data. Editing or pausing and resuming the monitor will refresh to the correct status. Additionally, disabling JPA caching in the configuration file also ensures timely data updates.
As demonstrated in the following GIF:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0a6ed3ea-c2ce-4598-a260-301637b34c02)

### Expected Behavior

After shutting down the service, the monitoring status correctly changes to down.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Environment

```markdown
HertzBeat version(s): master branch
```

### Debug logs

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

title: NA
body:
The root cause might be that `DataStorageDispatch` in the `warehouse` module uses `JdbcTemplate` to update the monitor status. However, `MonitorService` in the `manager` module queries data through JPA. Since updates from `JdbcTemplate` cannot be immediately perceived by JPA, the cached monitor object in JPA is not cleared in time, causing `MonitorService` to retrieve outdated data.

https://github.com/apache/hertzbeat/blob/4009525f81cd0641450050b60be4c456c76cad48/hertzbeat-warehouse/src/main/java/org/apache/hertzbeat/warehouse/store/DataStorageDispatch.java#L63-L107

title: NA
NA
body:
ğŸ‘ good solved way.  

The `calculateMonitorStatus` will be called very frequently, suggest not use `Transactional` it. 
How about consider clear or refresh jpa cache after `jdbcTemplate.update` as above.

title: NA
NA
body:
> How about this modification: removed transaction management, requires only one database operation (UPDATE), and clears the cache only when the status actually changes.

ok great
